of Molecular Catalysis, 61 (1990) 1-17 1 A NEW SILICA-SUPPORTED PLATINUM-AMINE CATALYST FOR THE REACTION OF SILANES WITH ALCOHOLS H. S. HILAL*, A. RABAH, I. S. KHATIB Chemistry Department, An-Najah N. University, P.O. Box 7,Nablus, West Bank (via Israel) and A. F. SCHREINER Department of Chemistry, North Carolina State University Box 8204, Raleigh, N.C. 27695-8204 (U.SA.) (Received February 9,1988; revised January 18, 1990) Summary A supported platinum catalyst has been prepared and evaluated for the reactions ofHSiRa (R = Et, OEt) and Me3SiOSi(H)(Me)OSiMe3 with alcohols ROH (R= Me, Et, n-Pr, i-Pr, t-Bu). The supporting surface was prepared by a condensation reaction of (EtC^Si with the ligand (ROaSiCHaCHgCHaNHa in the presence of water. The catalyst partially retains its activity on recovery after three different reaction times. Moreover, the catalytic activity is highly reproducible within the same batch, and among different prepared batches. Variation of the types of silanes and of the alcohols affects the rate of the reaction. The reaction is first order with respect to the catalyst and the silane. A first-order reaction with respect to alcohol is observed at low concentrations, whereas at higher concentrations the rate is independent of the alcohol concentration. There is no evidence of a reaction between the supported amine ligand and the silane. The effects of temperature, solvent polarity and added Uganda are also reported. Introduction 0-Silylation reactions (eqn. (1)) have been homogeneously catalyzed by a variety of transition metal complexes such as those of cobalt [1-4], iron [5], manganese [6], rhodium [7], indium [7,8] and platinum [9], RaSi H + H OR' -* RaSi OR' + H H (1) Homogeneous catalysts have several advantages, i.e. all active sites are accessible to reactants, their properties are easily modified and can be studied easily by conventional means. However, heterogeneous systems have the advantages of being easy to recover, stable to decomposition inside the reactor and generally of lower price. Supported catalysts are thus expected to *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/90/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands H,0 (EtO^Sl + (RO)3S1 - CH, - CH, - CH, - L > [catalyst] 1- ^ L o si -CH, - CH,- CH^ 0 Sl -CH, - CH,- CH^ - L - 0-^ J- ^ [M] - 0-^ _^ -0 si - CM 3 - CH, - CH 3 - L > M - 0-"^ Scheme 1. combine the advantages of both homogeneous and heterogeneous systems [10-15]. They have already been used in hydrogenation [16,17], hydrofor- mylation [18-22], 0-silylation [23, 24, 31] and other reactions [32, 33]. On supported catalysts, the ligand is anchored to the surface by condensation reactions. A few of these catalysts are reported to have some disadvantages, such as poor reproducibility and leaching of the catalyst [23]. Recently a new method of preparation of supported ligands has been reported [25], based on a condensation reaction between the ligand and (EtO)4Si (in the solution form) to produce the solid support (Scheme 1). Despite the possibility of burial or steric blocking of some of the ligand molecules inside the bulk of the support, this method of preparing solid supports is a very convenient one. Here we report our observations on the catalytic activity of supported chloroplatinic acid in 0-silylation reactions using an amine ligand as a linkage [26]. Experimental Hexachloroplatinic acid (HgPtCle^HaO) and sodium tetrachloro- platinate(II) (NagPtCLt solution) were purchased from Merck Chemical Company in pure form. HaPtCle^HgO was dissolved and stored in i-PrOH. The silanes were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Company, Inc. All solvents and alcohols were deoxygenated and dried by standard methods prior to use [27,28]. Analytical data were provided by the Microanalytical Laboratory of the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technol- ogy. IR spectra were obtained with a Pye Unicam SP3 200 spectrophot- ometer. Gas chromatographic analysis was carried out using a Pye Unicam gas chromatograph with a F.I.D., equipped with a 1.5m column. The stationary phase was PEG 20m 2K 931 Pye Unicam column. Nitrogen carrier gas with a flow rate of 40 ml min 1 was used, and the oven temperature was set at 60 C. UV/Visible spectra of the supported Pt species were measured with a Hitachi 110 spectrophotometer. Preparation of the solid support The supported amine ligand was prepared as described by Khatib [25,29]. Tetraethoxysilane, (EtC^Si (20.0 g, 0.096 mol), and HgO (4.75 g, 0.26 mol) were stirred together while cooling. The amine ligand, (EtOsSiCHaCHaCHgNHa (10.6g, 0.048 mol), was added to the stirred mixture. Within a few minutes a solid appeared, which was crushed and dried in an oven overnight. It was then ground, sieved (with the range 40-100 mesh) and washed with water several times. The solid was then filtered and dried overnight. Supported hexachloroplatinic acid The solid support was added to a solution of HgPtCle in i-PrOH (0.0558 M) with continuous shaking at room temperature overnight. The resulting yellow solid was then filtered, washed several times with i-PrOH and dried under nitrogen at room temperature. Table 1 shows the amounts of support and Pt solution used for the preparation of each batch, together with the time of shaking. Microanalytical data are shown in Table 2. Supported tetrachloroplatinate (II) The solid support (2.0 g) was stirred with an aqueous solution of NagPtC^ (25.0ml, Pt= 1.0%) at room temperature overnight. The solid was then washed with distilled water and dried at 50 C for 48 h. Analytical data are shown in Table 2. Solid state electronic absorption spectra were recorded for the supported platinum complex, which was first powdered and suspended in acetone. A clean quartz cell surface was painted with the acetone-solid suspension. The acetone was then evaporated, leaving a thin uniform layer of the supported complex on the cuvette surface. The spectra were recorded against a background of aminated solid support. Catalytic reactions All reactions were carried out in a 100ml round-bottomed flask fitted with a suba-seal, a nitrogen gas inlet and outlet, a magnetic stirrer, a thennostatted water bath and a constant-pressure gas burette. The catalyst, ligand, solvent (enough to make total volume 10ml) and the silane were placed in the reaction flask under a stream of nitrogen at the desired temperature. Ten minutes later the nitrogen flow was stopped and the system was leakage-tested. The gas burette was then set to zero and the alcohol injected by syringe. When higher temperatures were used for lighter alcohols (60 C and above), blank experiments were done to correct for burette readings due to the alcohol vapor pressure. These experiments were conducted in the absence of the catalyst. A maximum burette reading of 14 ml was recorded in these experiments. Results and discussion Addition of the alcohol to the stirred catalytic mixture (solid supported catalyst in solvent containing the silane) resulted in hydrogen gas evolution. At higher temperatures, blank experiments were needed to calculate the burette readings due to evaporated higher alcohols; these experiments without a catalyst were done in parallel with the catalytic ones. The blank experiment curves (burette reading us. time) were thus subtracted from the catalytic ones in order to calculate the corrected volume of hydrogen gas evolved. The rate of evolution of hydrogen coincided with the rate of decay of the v(Si-H) IR band at 2210 cm"1, and with the rate of decay of RaSiH and ROH peaks in the gas chromatogram. Reactions were thus monitored at constant pressure by measuring the volume of hydrogen gas evolved. (EtCOaSiH was investigated separately. Compared to the supported coun- terpart, the homogeneous catalyst showed no detectable activity below 70 C. However, at 70 C and higher, fast reactions were initially observed with rapid darkening and precipitation of a catalyst decomposition product. Neither the solid form nor the filtrate of the mixture showed observable catalytic activity on re-use. However, Table 3 shows that for the reaction ofEtaSiH and n-PrOH, the homogeneous HaPtCle-GHaO catalyst is more efficient than our supported catalyst. This appears from comparison of turnover numbers for the platinum catalysts after 5 min reaction times. Attempts were made to study the homogeneous catalytic system of HgPtCle-eHgO with (EtO)3Si(CH2)sNH2 (1:2 molar ratio), for comparison purposes. When mixed together in toluene, these two compounds formed a yellowish insoluble precipitate. HgPtCIc also gave an insoluble yellow precipitate on addition of other amines, such as EtgNH. Due to the precipitate formation, the homogeneous Pt amine catalytic system could not be studied in toluene. The literature also does not show supported platinum complexes used as catalysts for 0-silylation reactions. Therefore comparison of our supported catalysts with supported-Pt catalysts reported in the literature could not be done at this time. Supported hexachloroplatinic acid showed remarkable catalytic activity, whereas supported tetrachloroplatinate(II) was inactive. Thus, unless otherwise stated, all reactions shown below were carried out using hexachlo- roplatinic acid. Six batches of this supported catalyst were used, and the analytical data are shown in Table 1. Recovery and re-use Similar to other supported catalytic systems reported before [32], the catalyst had lost its activity on recovery (Fig. 11). This was obvious when higher reaction temperatures were used. Furthermore, the method of stirring affected the activity of the recovered catalyst. Magnetic stirring resulted in grinding or frictional wear of the solid catalyst, which affected its properties. This problem has been solved by using a mechanical stirrer. The loss of activity of the recovered catalyst may be due to one (or more) of the following: (i) Leaching of metal complex centres from the support. This type problem has been reported elsewhere [24]. In addition, the liquid phase separated from the reaction mixture failed to catalyze 0-silylation reactions.) (ii) Decomposition of the supported platinum com- plexes, on exposure to the hydrogen being produced. Equation (10) is thus consistent with our observations, in which the reaction is first order with respect to the catalyst and to the silane. The reaction is first order with respect to the alcohol when used at low concentrations, and zero order at high concentrations, which parallels eqn. (10). Alcohol molecules tend to associate at higher concentration, which may inhibit the nucleophilic attack. 16 Furthermore, if eqn. (4) is the rate-determining step, the proposed mechanism explains the effect of the type of alcohol reacting. With higher branching, steric hindrance increases and inhibits the nucleophilic attack. The fact that n-PrOH and i-PrOH react faster than EtOH is presumably due to an inductive effect, where the propyi group is known to be a better electron-donor than the ethyl group. The mechanism also explains why EtsSiH reacts faster than (EtOgSiH. With ethoxy groups, which are electron-withdrawing, the coordinated Si atom would accumulate a higher partial positive charge, which induces higher Pt Si back-bonding. Con- sequently the Pt Si bond becomes more difficult to break. Furthermore, the coordinated Si atom in the case of (EtO)sSiH and (HcaSiOgSKHKMe) is surrounded by bulky groups which tend to inhibit the nucleophilic attack. Use of polar solvents and/or addition of Lewis bases (e.g. PPha) slows the reaction. These Lewis bases presumably block the partially positive Si centres, and prevent the nucleophilic attack of the alcohol molecules at them. Box 7, Nablus, West Bank via Israel Department of Chemistry, North Carolina State University Box 8204, Raleigh, N.C. 27695-8204 U.S.A. 1 Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. A supported platinum catalyst has been prepared and evaluated for the reactions of HSiR3 (R = Et, OEt) and Me3SiOSi(H)(Me)OSiMe3 with alcohols ROH (R = Me, Et, n-Pr, i-Pr, t-Bu). The supporting surface was prepared by a condensation reaction of (EtO)4Si with the ligand (RO)3SiCH2CH2CH2NH2 in the presence of water. The catalyst partially retains its activity on recovery after three different reaction times. Moreover, the catalytic activity is highly reproducible within the same batch, and among different prepared batches. Variation of the types of silanes and of the alcohols affects the rate of the reaction. The reaction is first order with respect to the catalyst and the silane. A first-order reaction with respect to alcohol is observed at low concentrations, whereas at higher concentrations the rate is independent of the alcohol concentration. There is no evidence of a reaction between the supported amine ligand and the silane. The effects of temperature, solvent polarity and added ligands are also reported. References 1 H.S.
